work.p: Sentences from this manuscript were used in the "Health, Old Style" section of Good-Bye My Fancy (1891). The clipping of George Davis Harley's poem "Health" (1797), that Whitman pastes on this manuscript, is also printed in the "Health, Old Style" section of the volume.

p.ref: Sentences in this manuscript, as well as ideas expressed in it appear in the "Conclusion," section of the final installment of Whitman's journalistic series "Manly Health and Training," which was printed in twelve installments and ran in the New York Atlasfrom September 12, 1858 to December 26, 1858.
The "Health, Old Style" section of Whitman's Good-Bye My Fancy (1891) was later included in Whitman's Complete Prose Works (Philadelphia: David McKay, 1892).

note.p: This manuscript is a draft of the prose section "Health, Old Style," which was published in Whitman's book Good-Bye My Fancy, 2nd Annex to Leaves of Grass (Philadelphia: David McKay, 1891). This manuscript page consists of a pasted on manuscript in Whitman's hand, prose notes in Whitman's hand, including both printing instructions and notes that would later contribute to a headnote that accompanied a poem entitled "Health," that was also printed in the "Health, Old Style," section of Whitman's Good-Bye My Fancy, 2nd Annex to Leaves of Grass (Philadelphia: David McKay, 1891).

This manuscript includes a clipping of the poem "Health," written by "George Davies (G. D.) Harley," which spans two pages. This poem was first published in the June 1797 issue of the The Monthly Mirror, a London magazine. It was reprinted in Harley's book Ballad Stories, Sonnets, &c. (Bath, Printed by R. Cruttwell), I:35–36. The copy Whitman pasted into a scrapbook, according to his notes, then clipped and pasted onto this manuscript may be taken from The American Poetical Miscellany (Vol. 1, 1809) based on the wording of the line "Yet bids the biting blast more fiercely blow" (191). The wording of this line of the poem does not match that found in either The Monthly Mirror or Ballad Stories, Sonnets, &c., but it does match that in the The American Poetical Miscellany.
Whitman has not pasted the entire printed poem on the manuscript. He writes the last two stanzas in black ink on a blank section of the scrapbook page that he pasted onto the manuscript.

The "Perfect Health" manuscript, that has been pasted onto this manuscript draft of the "Health, Old Style," section of Good-Bye My Fancy, is written on what is almost certainly a blue Williamsburgh tax form. This manuscript may be related to Whitman's prose notes, also on Blue Williamsburgh tax forms, that are now part of what is known as the "Physique" Notebook or the Notebook on "Physique," which is now part of The Thomas Biggs Harned Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1842–1937, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C. Whitman likely wrote "Perfect Health," in 1857 or 1858 since the manuscript includes numerous words and phrases that appear in the "Conclusion" section of the final installment of Whitman's newspaper series, "Manly Health and Training," which appeared in the New York Atlas on December 26, 1858. Whitman seemingly preserved this page and the other materials in the Physique Notebook for more than thirty years before revising the material that appears in "Perfect Health" (and by extension that appeared in "Manly Health") to more fully describe his physical health and its decline during his final years.

body.head: Condition of Perfect Health.—
body.p:
In that condition the whole body is elevated to a state generallyby others persons states unknown—inwardly and outwardly illuminated, purified, made solid, strong, yet buoyant.—A singular charm, more than beauty, flickers out of, and over, the face—a curious transparancy beams in the eyes, both in the iris and the white——The temper partakes also. Nothing that happens
—no event, rencontre, weather, &c.–but
presents it is confronted—nothing but is subdued into
sustenance such is the marvellous transformations from the old timorousness and the old process of causes and effects.—Sorrows and disappointments cease—there is no more borrowing trouble in advance. A man realizes the
old venerable
myth–he is a god walking the earth; he sees new eligibilities, powers and beauties everywhere; he himself has new faculties, a new eyesight and hearing:— The play of the body, in motion,
has then takes
a previous unknown grace—MerlyMerely to move is then a happiness a pleasure—to breathe, to see, is also.—All the All the beforehand gratifications, drink spirits, coffee, grease, stimulants,mixtures late hours' luxurious, luxuries, deeds of the night
line me seem as vexatious dreams,—and now the awakening;—
as many
also take fall into their natural places, wholesome, conveying, diviner joys
ôWhat I append Health, Old Style I have long treasur'd—found originally in some old scrap-book fifty years ago— old style—a favorite of mine (but quite a glaring contrast to my present bodily state:)

lg.l: ON a high rock above the vast abyss,
Whose solid base tumultuous waters lave;
Whose airy high-top balmy breezes kiss,
Fresh from the white foam of the circling wave:—
There ruddy HEALTH, in rude majestic state,
His clust'ring forelock combatting the winds—
Bares to each season's change his breast elate,
And still fresh vigor from th' encounter finds:
With mighty mind to every fortune brac'd,
To every climate each corporeal power,
And high-proof heart, impenetrably cas'd,
He mocks the quick transitions of the hour.
Now could he hug bleak Zembla's bolted snow,
Now to Arabia's heated desarts turn,
Yet bids the biting blast more fiercely blow,
The scorching sun without abatement burn.
There this bold Outlaw, rising with the morn,
His sinewy functions fitted for the toil
Pursues, with tireless steps, the rapturous horn,
And bears in triumph back the shaggy spoil.
Or, on his rugged range of towering hills,
Turns the stiff giebe behind his hardy team;
His wide-spread heaths to blithest measures tills,
And boasts the joys of life are not a dream!
Then to his airy hut, at eve, retires,
Clasps to his open breast his buxom spouse,
Basks in his faggot's blaze, his passions fires
And strait supine to rest his unbroken bows.
On his smooth forehead, Time's old annual score,
Tho' left to furrow, yet disdains to lie;
He bids weak sorrow tantalize no more,
And puts the cup of care contemptuous by.
If, from some inland height, that, skirting, bears
Its rude encroachments far into the vale,
He views where poor dishonor'd nature wears
On her soft cheek alone the lily pale;
How will he scorn alliance with the race,
Those aspin shoots that shiver at a breath;
Children of sloth, that danger dare not face;
And finds in life but an extended death;
Then from the silken reptiles will he fly
To the bold cliff in bounding transports run,
And stretch'd o'er many a wave his ardent eye,
Embrace the enduring sea-boy as his son!
Yes! thine alone—from pain, from sorrow free,
The lengthen'd life with peerless joys replete;
Then let me, Lord of Mountains, share with thee,
The the hard, the early toil—the relaxation sweet.
